name: Blackeswell
tagline: Isolated Mulchgrove village, nearing the utmost decay of its former wealth
description: A village of finely-built houses and stores, slowly falling into disrepair. Blackeswell is situated beside a stinking pool in the isolated northern reaches of Mulchgrove, now subsumed in the slowly expanding fungal forest.
atmosphere: An eerie emptiness pervades, with the ever present stench of the Blacke wafting through abandoned buildings that remind of past prosperity
inhabitants_description: A proud and somewhat inbred folk who cling to the remnants of their ancestors' prosperity. Visitors to Blackeswell are rare, and new settlers ever rarer (though its isolation appeals to a certain type of eccentric). The people have pallid skin with a distinct greenish tinge visible under candlelight from drinking the contaminated water of the Blacke.

governance.ruling_body: council of representatives of six guilds—the guilds of tailors, lenders, taverners, masons, jewellers, and chandlers
governance.notes: The tailor, Sylvain Aster, is the elected leader of the council

religion.religious_practices: The ostentatious and fastidiously maintained church of St Gondyw on the village square is by far the largest remaining building in the settlement. Characters praying may receive the blessing of St Gondyw: the ability to cast Bless.

history: Blackeswell was founded at the site of a rich vein of Hag Iron, a rare metal renowned for its curative properties when crafted into jewellery

Wagon-loads of the metal were exported from the village to Castle Brackenwold and trade brought great prosperity—a thriving marketplace, amenities to entertain merchants, and artisans' workshops soon followed
Blackeswell gained a reputation as a place of good taste and exquisite craftsmanship
200 years ago, the vein of Hag Iron began to dry up. Trade slowed, as ever smaller quantities of the metal were extracted
Eventually the mine was exhausted and trade halted. Blackeswell's reputation faded and the village became little more than a curiosity on old maps
The population of Blackeswell has greatly diminished since the village's heyday and many once-proud buildings have been abandoned
current_events: The mysterious outsider Mr Klepp, said to be of Castle Brackenwold, recently purchased an old warehouse in Blackeswell and has moved in all manner of odd equipment
Agents of the equally enigmatic Mr Paronax are said to be eyeing derelict buildings for purchase
The vicar, Father Bertil, and the council leader, Sylvain Aster, secretly plot to discover more about the outsiders' (presumably nefarious) schemes

special_features.name: The Blacke
special_features.description: A foetid pool that was once a cheery stream, now choked with silt and stinking purple lilies. The villagers drink the stinking, green water with gusto, which lends their skin a pallid tint with a distinct greenish tinge visible under candlelight.
special_features.mechanical_effect: Outsiders who consume the unprocessed waters of the Blacke become sick, suffering from vomiting and shakes for 1d4 days (–1 penalty to Attack Rolls and Saving Throws)
special_features.affected_area: The entire settlement is pervaded by a fishy, rotting stench wafting from the pool

special_items: greenish-white rope made from fungal fibres harvested in Mulchgrove
equipment_availability.notes: Only rustic weapons (e.g. arrows, daggers, shortbows, slings, staves) are available. No form of armour can be bought in Blackeswell.

locations.name: The Blacke
locations.description: Once a cheery stream, shifting waters in Mulchgrove gradually transformed the Blacke into a foetid pool, choked with silt and stinking purple lilies.
locations.exterior: Long-disused fishing huts, now ruined and rotting, stand along the shore.
special_features: Source of contaminated water that gives villagers greenish skin tinge

locations.name: Village Square
locations.description: A broad, paved square, neatly maintained but seldom used.
locations.exterior: White marble statue of St Gondyw clad in mail, holding aloft a lantern and carrying an unfurled scroll. Comical diorama depicts three laughing maidens, waving coyly, pursued by a leering shorthorn. Locked brick watchtower with rickety wooden lookout.

locations.name: Church of St Gondyw
locations.description: A grand church in an unusual provincial style, worthy of a much larger town. A tall bell tower with a weathercockatrice at its apex overlooks the village.
locations.interior: An austere space of cold stone pews and stark pillars, with a plain marble altar. The only decoration is a huge portrait of St Gondyw staring down from the ceiling.
locations.exterior: Beautifully wrought doors of black iron. Graveyard ringed with iron railings, with an ornamental gate in the south-east corner.
locations.populace: The occasional devout local. Generally empty.

services.name: Prayer
services.description: Characters praying may receive the blessing of St Gondyw: the ability to cast Bless

special_features: Blessing of St Gondyw available through prayer

locations.name: Abandoned Mine
locations.description: A decrepit, tiled-roof building—the former headquarters of the Blackeswell Mining Co—stands beside the fenced-off mining pit which was the source of Blackeswell's former wealth.
locations.interior: Former headquarters of the Blackeswell Mining Co
locations.exterior: Decrepit, tiled-roof building beside fenced-off mining pit
special_features: Former source of Hag Iron that brought the village prosperity

locations.name: The Crooked Arm
locations.description: A homely, rural inn with a sagging, tiled roof. At the south-east corner, a closed hatch gives access to the cellar.
locations.interior: A gloomy space of black beams, sombre portraits, and pipesmoke-stained walls. The landlady, Arbie Snyde, serves from a solid oak counter.
locations.exterior: Homely, rural inn with sagging, tiled roof and cellar hatch
locations.populace: The occasional morose local or lone traveller

services.name: Stabling
services.description: Mounts are accommodated in the adjacent goat field, with no form of shelter

special_features: Sign: A Chapes holy symbol hanging in the crook of a flexed arm

locations.name: The Spigot and Gullet
locations.description: A low, one-storey tavern with a door on each side and numerous round, porthole-like windows. The thatched roof is topped with a wooden sea monster's head.
locations.interior: A round room with too few tables, too many chairs, and a wobbly drinks table at one side. Locals serve themselves, as the landlady, Gilly-Ann Locke, carouses and dances to the ever-present fiddle music.
locations.exterior: Low, one-storey building with porthole windows and sea monster head on roof
locations.populace: Merry, tipsy locals, dancing, boozing, and chewing the fat. An occasional pedlar selling wares.
locations.atmosphere: Merry and boisterous with ever-present fiddle music
special_features: Sign: A sea monster clutching ale kegs in its maw

locations.name: Council House
locations.description: A once-stately building of plastered stone, that is now beginning to crumble. A tower stands at the south-east corner, now home to a great colony of rooks.
locations.exterior: Once-stately building of plastered stone, now crumbling, with tower housing rooks
locations.populace: The council meets here once a month, but the building is otherwise little used
special_features: Tower home to great colony of rooks

locations.name: Fish Market
locations.description: The stink of fresh fish wafts from this low, tin-roofed marketplace. Most of the fish on sale are oddly green-hued and many have unusual features such as extra eyes, clusters of tentacles, human-like snouts, or two heads.

services.name: Fish
services.description: Oddly green-hued fish with unusual features
services.notes: Fish have extra eyes, clusters of tentacles, human-like snouts, or two heads

locations.name: Aster's Fine Costumery
locations.description: A tidy little store on the edge of the village. Mannequins stand outside, sporting outlandish waistcoats and caps.
locations.interior: Overbrimming with mannequins, display cases, and bolts of fabric. The tailor, Sylvain Aster, greets clients, while his aide, the dour Henricus Buttons, stitches furiously in the back room.
locations.exterior: Tidy little store with mannequins displaying outlandish clothing
locations.populace: Sylvain Aster and his aide Henricus Buttons

services.name: Fashionable outfits
services.description: Off the rack or tailored to order
services.notes: Aster's concept of fashion is highly idiosyncratic

locations.name: Klepp's Workshop
locations.description: A long, one-storey building that was recently purchased by a mysterious out-of-towner, Mr Klepp.
locations.interior: Crates of gears, rivets, and metal plates, watched by a clockwork guardian programmed to expel intruders.
locations.exterior: Long, one-storey building with shuttered windows and massive stone front door
locations.populace: Mr Klepp (not yet moved in) and clockwork guardian
special_features: Mr Klepp is an artificer specialising in clockwork automata
secrets: Mr Klepp is an artificer specialising in clockwork automata

locations.name: Fishfop Brewery
locations.description: A small brewery with a massive brick chimney, providing for all the village's spirituous needs. Clusters of barrels stand outside, reeking of fish and pondweed, their lids ajar and overbrimming with pale green foam.
locations.exterior: Small brewery with massive brick chimney and barrels outside
special_features: Provides all the village's spirituous needs

locations.name: Disused Granary
locations.description: A squat, square stone tower of two storeys overlooking the Blacke. A cacophony of croaking can often be heard from its empty windows and door frame.
locations.interior: A colony of 15 quag toads has taken up residence in the slime-drenched rooms of the ruin. They do not appreciate people poking around in their lair.
locations.exterior: Squat, square stone tower with empty windows and door frame

npcs.name: Sylvain Aster
npcs.title: Tailor and Council Leader
npcs.description: A broad-faced human man in his forties, with sparkling green eyes, a dazzling smile, prodigious red sideburns, and a shiny monocle.
npcs.dress: Dresses in paisley waistcoats, billowing silk pantaloons, and pompously plumed velvet caps.
npcs.mannerisms: Clasps his hands together in delight.
npcs.speech: Affectedly upper class. Seldom wishes to speak of non-sartorial matters. Woldish.
desires: To discover the intent of the outsiders Mr Klepp and Mr Paronax in Blackeswell and to convince the council to ban the sale of property to non-Blackeswellers
For his singular vision of costumery to be celebrated far and wide, bringing prosperity to Blackeswell once more
secrets: Secretly plots with Father Bertil to discover more about the outsiders' schemes
npcs.occupation: Tailor and elected leader of the council

npcs.name: Gilly-Ann Locke
npcs.title: Spigot and Gullet Proprietor
npcs.description: A busty human woman in her 60s, with curly locks and remarkably hairy ears.
npcs.mannerisms: Wipes her nose on her sleeve.
desires: To welcome Mr Klepp to the village by cooking his favourite food for him

npcs.name: Arbie Snyde
npcs.title: Crooked Arm Proprietor
npcs.description: A stooped, corpulent human woman in her fifties, with a mop of grey hair, pendulous jowls, and a peg leg.
npcs.mannerisms: Perpetually grimacing—as if she is the only villager who can smell the Blacke.

npcs.name: Father Ingram Bertil
npcs.title: Vicar of Blackeswell
npcs.description: An ageing, frizzy-haired human bachelor with bent spectacles and bristling, white eyebrows.
desires: To do as little work as possible—gladly lets the pious villagers take care of many of his duties
secrets: Secretly plots with Sylvain Aster to discover more about the outsiders' schemes

entries.description: Father Bertil (p126) snooping disapprovingly around Klepp's workshop, trying to peek through the shutters.
A ruined building collapses. 2d4 villagers begin clearing the rubble.
2d4 villagers erect precarious ladders and scaffolds around the church, preparing to clean its exterior.
2d4 mercenaries (Level 1 fighters—DMB) roll up in 1d4 wagons and proceed to unload at Klepp's workshop.
2d4 villagers hauling barrels of stinking water from the Blacke to the Fishfop brewery.
The landlady, Gilly-Ann Locke (p126), capering giddily through the square, singing raunchy ballads.
The innkeeper, Arbie Snyde (p126), poking around a derelict building, looking for abandoned treasures.
Sylvain Aster loitering by Klepp's workshop, listening for the tell-tale sounds of black magic.
The clockwork guardian (p127) bursts out of Klepp's workshop and runs amok.
An adventuring party (DMB) arrives, covered in sticky orange slime. (They have travelled through the fungal chasm in hex 1605.)
entries.notes: They have travelled through the fungal chasm in hex 1605

entries.description: A hungry ochre slime-hulk (DMB) wanders through, sniffing out fresh flesh.

monsters.name: Quag Toads
monsters.description: 2′ long, black-skinned toads with quizzically rotating eyeballs and mouths full of gnarled fangs.

special_abilities.name: Poison
special_abilities.description: Save Versus Doom or become sick for 1d10 days: –2 to Attack Rolls and Saving Throws, Speed reduced by half.

monsters.name: Clockwork Guardian
monsters.description: A hulking, 6′ tall, humanoid automaton of brass and bolts, powered by gears, springs, and coils.

special_abilities.name: Construct
special_abilities.description: Immune to biological effects (e.g. disease, poison) and mind-affecting spells (e.g. Vapours of Dream, Paralysation, Dominate).
